DOC.HEAD: Panel to Explore `Roots' of Corruption
DOC.TEXT: The scandal-plagued Department of Housing and Urban Development must establish ``a new level of credibility'' before Congress will back significant new housing programs, according to the head of a Senate panel that plans a new probe of the department. Sen. Bob Graham, D-Fla., chairman of the newly appointed subcommittee on HUD investigations, said multibillion-dollar abuses uncovered at HUD during the Reagan administration are the result of deep-rooted problems in the way the agency's housing subsidy programs are structured. He said his panel will open hearings soon after Congress reconvenes in January aimed at finding ways to change federal housing subsidies for the poor to make influence-peddling and mismanagement more difficult and more detectible. ``It may be that the plunder reached new heights during the Pierce era, but it is not by any means the first time there have been scandals similar to those that have come out in the last few months,'' Graham said, referring to former HUD Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. ``Our approach is going to be one of trying to understand and legislate on why these programs of HUD have been so subject to plunder for an extended period of time,'' Graham said. ``Clearly, the original objectives of these programs is not being achieved.'' Graham's investigative panel was appointed by Senate Banking Committee Chairman Don Riegle, D-Mich. He commented in a recent interview in his office during the congressional recess. Graham contended that a package of management reforms proposed by HUD Secretary Jack Kemp and enacted by Congress as one of its final actions before recessing for the year did not end all the potential for abuse in housing laws. He said developers continue to be able to ``layer'' their federal subsidies from HUD, combining multifamily housing grants with other subsidies, including low-income housing tax credits. Graham is among the Senate cosponsors of a bill that would overhaul most housing programs aimed to benefit low-income people, and which has been pushed strongly by advocates of increased federal housing aid. That legislation did not advance during this year's session, and Graham suggested it was unlikely to move until his panel makes its report. ``There has to be a new level of credibility in the department and in the programs before it is likely the Congress will support significant new housing initiatives,'' Graham said. Still, the Senate committee's move to investigate HUD has raised questions about its timing and motives, since furor over the fraud, influence-peddling and mismanagement at HUD seems to be fading after first gaining attention last spring. A House subcommittee headed by Rep. Tom Lantos, D-Calif., conducted nearly 30 hearings over eight months. It subpoenaed Pierce and his former aides _ prompting Pierce and three others to refuse to testify on grounds of self-incrimination. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh has begun a preliminary inquiry into whether a special prosecutor should be appointed to investigate Pierce. Graham's probe also comes as Kemp has voiced anger at Congress for appropriating millions of dollars to specific HUD projects that the department's own staff says is unnecessary or wasteful. Talbot ``Sandy'' D'Alemberte, a Florida attorney hired by Graham to lead the panel's staff, said the probe would not focus on the scandal's ``rats,'' as the Lantos probe did, and would not create the sensation that the House panel did with its parade of witnesses invoking 5th Amendment rights. D'Alemberte is a former dean of the Florida State University Law School and president-elect of the American Bar Association. Graham said his panel would focus instead on ``vulnerability'' to abuse in housing laws and probably would not try to compel testimony from witnesses who have refused before the Lantos panel. He said it would conclude hearings in 60 to 90 days.
